p.s: There are places, where I wouldn't let my daughters go to by any means - Jérôme Boateng
If you consider going abroad and spending an exchange year in Germany, it is important to acknowledge that racism againgstagainst people of colour is apparent.
Especially people with African heritage still get discrimminateddiscriminated often and have to prepare themselves for the case of an attack.
As an international culture exchange organization it is our duty to inform and educate on that matter.
Being a German volunteer myself, this subject is really important to me and I tried to do my best on shaping a picture of the daily life as a black person in Germany.

Thus, I researched online and came across an article about Jérôme Boateng, a German soccer player who recently changed teams from first playing on the national German team, then the very successfullsuccessful Bavarian team FC Bayern München to now playing on the Olympique Lyon team in France, Lyon.
Jérôme Boateng grew up in Germany, he is German.
However, his skin colour is black and because of that, he recalls to have had many traumatizing experiences throughout his life.
The very least understandable in his childhood, of course.
Someone once shouted Hey, my little nigger at him at an age, where Boateng did not even understand excactlyexactly how people could have a problem with skin colours in the first place.
These racist incidents often take place in a soccer-/sports surrounding, states Boateng on an interview together with the famous German singer, Herbert Grönemeyer.
Sometimes, when he is warming himself up, Boateng has to listen to people making monkey noises.
Still, even though he has achieved so much in soccer, in Germany in general.
The whole situation apparentelyapparently got worse after the migration crisis in Europe, which started around 2015.

Since many people fled from their home countries in Syria or AfgahnistanAfghanistan (due to the wars and horrible living conditions), people fear now that there is not enough space in Germany for all of them.

Even some, who grew up in Germany, but do not look typically German (blond, blue-eyed - old stereotypes) because of their parents being first generation immigrants or just beacuse they generally have a darker skin tone, get looked at more and more sceptically in daily life.
Still, Jérôme Boateng thinks it is important to mention that this incidents are by far in the minority.
Many people experience every day (...) what an achievement it is to live in such a colourful (diverse) country, states Jérôme.

Boateng, having played in the soccer world championchipchampionship in 2014 for Germany (and that successfully), states that this would probably not have been possible without all the German players of different origin.
Even though he once did suffer so much from racist commentary, Boateng nowadays is able to let these incidents not get to him that much.
We sincerely hope that this blog post will not stop you from following your dream as an exchange students in Germany.

Because our belief as an exchange organisation is that every society has its own struggles and the only way to overcome prejudices and discrimminationdiscrimination istis to exchange cultures, ideas and life experiences.
We wish you all the best on your journey!
